para.text: The benefits of learning a foreign language.
Briefly state what your topic is.
the benefits of learning a foreign language.
Give a brief overview of the structure of your talk and how you will deal with the topic.
three important benefits of learning another language:
The first benefit I shall describe is
practical—speaking another language means we can communicate with other nationalities.
increased cultural understanding—when people can speak the same language, this breaks down barriers and bridges the gap between cultures.
The final benefit that I shall describe is
improved cognitive skills. Research shows that learning another language increases our brain power.
This is the longest part. It should be clearly organized in a logical way.
Elaborate on the three benefits mentioned in the overview.

content.placeHolder: Type your outline of the talk here

para.text: Summarize your points. Make any recommendations or suggestions for further work. Invite questions.

I believe it is clear that there are huge benefits to be gained from learning a foreign language. I would even go so far as to say that it should be compulsory for all school children to learn at least one language for several years. The benefits that it will bring to them and society in general are too great to be ignored. I have never regretted the work I have put into learning English.
If anyone has any questions, I would be very pleased to try to answer them.

steps.label: How should I organize my talk?
desc: There are many different ways you can organize your ideas and arguments in a presentation. Which you choose will depend partly on how long your talk is going to be but mainly on your topic.
In many ways, preparing a talk is similar to preparing an essay—the talk needs to be organized and structured, with a beginning, a middle and an end.

checkList.text: Make sure that you prepare really well.
Do your reading and research and make notes on the topic you are presenting.
Think about the purpose of your talk. Is it to inform, entertain or to persuade your audience?
Think about your audience and how much they already know.
Note that it is always best to speak from notes rather than reading out the full talk.
Prepare for questions.

checkList.text: Make notes in English on cards.
checkList.tellMeMore:
• Number your cards.

  • Note the number of the visual you will show.

  • Write out and highlight key words and phrases to guide your audience through your talk.

  • Some people find it helpful to write out the whole introduction and conclusion.

checkList.text: Write out any parts that you feel you need to, for example the introduction and conclusion.
Write out and highlight key words and phrases to guide your audience through your talk.
Prepare visual aids.
checkList.tellMeMore:
• If you use PowerPoint™, all text and charts, diagrams, etc. must be large and clear.

  • Do not put too much information on each slide.

  • Leave lots of white space.

  • Use headings and bullet points to show the relationship between ideas.

  • Use notes, not sentences.

  • If you use posters or pictures, check that the people at the back of the room will be able to see/read them.

  • Avoid writing/drawing things on a whiteboard during your talk.

checkList.text: Practise your talk.
checkList.tellMeMore:
The more you practise, the more confident you will feel and the better your talk will be.

  • First, practise your talk alone several times until you can speak fluently and confidently from your notes and keep to the time allowed.

  • Then practise with one or more friends listening. Is the talk clear? Is your voice loud and clear? Are you looking at the audience?

  • If you can, practise at least once with the equipment you will use and in the room where you will give the talk.

  • Remember to use your dictionary to check the pronunciation of any words you are not sure about as well as vocabulary and grammar.
